type BindingListCollectionView = class inherit CollectionView interface IComparer interface IEditableCollectionView interface ICollectionViewLiveShaping interface IItemProperties

Docs.summary: Represents the for collections that implement , such as Microsoft ActiveX Data Objects (ADO) data views.

remarks.format:
## Remarks All collections have a default <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView>. For collections that implement <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingListView> or <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingList>, the default collection view is <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView>. Specifically, <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingList> is required for <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView>, and <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingListView> is an optional interface that gives additional sorting and filtering support.
If you have multiple <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects and the underlying source is a `DataTable` or a `DataView`, the view objects do not sort or filter independently. For example, if you have two <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects associated with the same `DataTable` and you perform sorting on one of the views, the order of items in the other view can be affected. This is because <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects use the underlying <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingList> for sorting and filtering functionalities.
For more information about collection views, see [Data Binding Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/data/data-binding-overview.md).

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance object AddNew() cil managed
abstract member AddNew : unit -> obj override this.AddNew : unit -> obj

Docs.summary: Starts an add transaction and returns the pending new item.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Calling <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.AddNew%2A> begins an add transaction. You should call <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CommitNew%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CancelNew%2A> to end the add transaction. A new item always appears in the collection view. Any filtering, sorting, or grouping that is applied to the view is applied to the new item when <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CommitNew%2A> is called.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property CanAddNew As Boolean
public: property bool CanAddNew { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether a new item can be added to the collection.
Docs.value: if a new item can be added to the collection; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> can create a new item for the collection if there is not an edit transaction occurring, if the collection is not a fixed size, and if the collection is not read-only.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property CanCancelEdit As Boolean
public: property bool CanCancelEdit { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the collection view can discard pending changes and restore the original values of an edited object.
Docs.value: if the collection view can discard pending changes and restore the original values of an edited object; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CanCancelEdit%2A> is `true` if the edited item implements the <xref:System.ComponentModel.IEditableObject?displayProperty=nameWithType> interface. If <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CanCancelEdit%2A> is `false`, call <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CancelEdit%2A> to cause the view to exit the edit state and provide logic to revert the changes on the object that was edited.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void CancelEdit() cil managed
abstract member CancelEdit : unit -> unit override this.CancelEdit : unit -> unit

Docs.summary: Ends the edit transaction and, if possible, restores the original value to the item.

remarks.format: ## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CancelEdit%2A> sets <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CurrentEditItem%2A> to `null` and causes the collection view to exit the edit state. If <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CanCancelEdit%2A> is `true`, <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CancelEdit%2A> also restores the original values of the edited object.

Docs.summary: Returns a value that indicates whether a given item belongs to the collection view.
Docs.returns: if the item belongs to the collection view; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This method does not make any assumptions about whether the item belongs to the underlying collection. If you know that the item belongs to the underlying collection, it is more efficient to call <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.PassesFilter%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: Public Overrides ReadOnly Property Count As Integer
public: virtual property int Count { int get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the estimated number of records in the collection.
Docs.value:
One of the following:
Value
Meaning
-1
Could not determine the count of the collection. This might be returned by a "virtualizing" view, where the view deliberately does not account for all items in the underlying collection because the view is attempting to increase efficiency and minimize dependence on always having the entire collection available.
any other integer
The count of the collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Note that this count represents the filtered count.

Attribute.AttributeName: get: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a custom filter.
Docs.value: A string that specifies how the items are filtered.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CanCustomFilter%2A> property to test whether the view supports custom filtering before assigning a string to this property.
The syntax depends on the <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingListView> implementation. For an example of the supported filter expression syntax, see <xref:System.Data.DataView.RowFilter%2A>.
Note that if you have multiple <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects and the underlying source is a `DataTable` or a `DataView`, the view objects do not sort or filter independently. For example, if you have two <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects associated with the same `DataTable` and you perform sorting on one of the views, the order of items in the other view can be affected. This is because <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects use the underlying <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingList> for sorting and filtering functionalities.

MemberSignature.Value: Public Overrides ReadOnly Property GroupDescriptions As ObservableCollection(Of GroupDescription)

Docs.summary: Gets a collection of objects that describe how the items in the collection are grouped in the view.
Docs.value: A collection of objects that describe how the items in the collection are grouped in the view.

remarks.format:
## Remarks
> [!NOTE] > This property can only be set by accessing the collection object and using its various methods such as Add. The property to access the collection object itself is read-only; the collection itself is read/write.
## Examples The following example shows how to use this property:
[!code-csharp[DataBindingLab#6](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/DataBindingLab/CSharp/MainWindow.xaml.cs#6)] [!code-vb[DataBindingLab#6](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/DataBindingLab/VisualBasic/MainWindow.xaml.vb#6)]
For the complete example, see [Data Binding Demo](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=163703).

public: property bool IsAddingNew { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether an add transaction is in progress.
Docs.value: if an add transaction is in progress; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks You begin an add transaction by calling the <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView.AddNew%2A> method, and you end the add transaction by calling <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView.CommitNew%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView.CancelNew%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property bool IsDataInGroupOrder { bool get(); void set(bool value); };
member this.IsDataInGroupOrder : bool with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the list of items (after applying the sort and filters, if any) is already in the correct order for grouping.
Docs.value: if the list of items is already in the correct order for grouping; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Setting this property to `true` informs the view that the list of items is already in the correct order for grouping and allows the view to use a more efficient algorithm to build the groups. The data is in the correct order if:
1. All items belonging to a given group appear consecutively, and
2. If the <xref:System.ComponentModel.GroupDescription.GroupNames%2A> collection is non-empty, the groups in <xref:System.ComponentModel.GroupDescription.GroupNames%2A> appear before any other groups, and in the same order as in <xref:System.ComponentModel.GroupDescription.GroupNames%2A>.

public: property bool IsEditingItem { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether an edit transaction is in progress.
Docs.value: if an edit transaction is in progress; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks You begin an edit transaction by calling the <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView.EditItem%2A> method, and you end the transaction by calling <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView.CommitEdit%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView.CancelEdit%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance bool PassesFilter(object item) cil managed
Public Overrides Function PassesFilter (item As Object) As Boolean

Docs.summary: Returns a value that indicates whether the specified item in the underlying collection belongs to the view.
Docs.returns: if the specified item belongs to the view or if there is not filter set on the collection view; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Unlike the <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.Contains%2A> method, this method assumes that the specified item belongs to the underlying collection. This method takes filters into account. Typically, you use this method during collection-changed notifications to determine if the added or removed item requires processing.

Docs.summary: Removes the specified item from the collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks If `item` is not in the collection, <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.Remove%2A> does nothing.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void RemoveAt(int32 index) cil managed
abstract member RemoveAt : int -> unit override this.RemoveAt : int -> unit

Docs.param: The zero-based index of the item to remove.
Docs.summary: Removes the item at the specified position from the collection.

remarks.format: ## Remarks `index` is relative to the collection view, not the collection. For example, if the collection has 10 items and the view has a <xref:System.ComponentModel.ICollectionView.Filter%2A> so that 7 items appear, the valid values of `index` are 0 through 6.

Docs.exception: is less than 0 or greater than the number of items in the collection view.

## Remarks Note that if you have multiple <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects and the underlying source is a `DataTable` or a `DataView`, the view objects do not sort or filter independently. For example, if you have two <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects associated with the same `DataTable` and you perform sorting on one of the views, the order of items in the other view can be affected. This is because <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects use the underlying <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingList> for sorting and filtering functionalities.
> [!NOTE] > This property can only be set by accessing the collection object and using its various methods such as `Add`. The property to access the collection object itself is read-only; the collection itself is read/write.
